newsitem.title: USA: Maine's Gov says revenues slip in Nov but on track.
newsitem.headline: Maine's Gov says revenues slip in Nov but on track.

text.p: Maine Gov Angus King on Friday said that while general fund revenues were slightly lower than budgeted in November, they remain "well ahead" of estimates for the year.
Year-to-date revenues, including November's collections, which fell four percent below budget, exceeded projections by $15.4 million or two percent, King said, in prepared remarks.

Maine attributed the drop in November's revenues in part due to a shorter tax-processing period, and noted it does not contain sales tax revenues from Christmas, which King said many analysts said had been strong in the state.
"State revenues continue to show the economy is on track and growing at a steady, if modest rate. We expect to see this trend continue for the foreseeable future," he added.
In November, general fund revenues totaled $124.9 million, with sales tax receipts adding up to almost $52.9 million, slightly under projections but three percent above the year-ago period.

Individual income tax receipts totaled almost $42.5 million, eight percent below target for the month, but one percent above projections for the year. Corporate income tax receipts were $750,422, down 58 percent for the month, but 74 percent higher for the year-to-date.
